trial_identification.scientifictitle: The endotracheal tube and endotracheal suction: An exploration of the patient experience in: Adult Cardiac Surgical Intensive Care patients.

interventions.interventions: This is a qualitative study, investigating the patient experience of the endotracheal tube and endotracheal suction. The intervention is a patient interview prior to discharge. The interview will take approximately 15-30 minutes and will be conducted on day 4-6 post-operatively . The suction will be performed both when the patient is sedated and awake prior to extubation. This is standard care in post operative cardiac surgical patients. Patients will have pain relief as required.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Patient experience of the endotracheal tube and endotracheal suction. This qualitative study will be assessed by semi-structured interview following surgery and prior to discharge.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Pain assessment. This will be assessed with both a validated behavioral pain scale while the patient is sedated and once the patient is awake a validated numerical pain scale will be used. Patient self reported scores are the gold standard for pain assessment and management. The validated behavioral pain tool used will be Critical Care Pain Observation Tool.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: During endotracheal suction, while sedated and ventilated and during suction once the patient is awake but intubated.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. 16 years old and over 2. Patients who have had cardiac surgery with cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB), 3. Extubation within 12 hours of admission to CVICU.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Ventilated for over 12 hours. 2. Non-English speaking 3. Documented chronic pain

fundingsource.fundingname: Health Research Council, New Zealand - Scholarship funding

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of this study is to investigate the patient experience of both the endotracheal tube and endotracheal suction. In addition there will be a comparison of two pain assessment tools while the patient is in intensive care.
